summary: When patients can’t tell you their symptoms
title: When patients can’t tell you their symptoms
body:
Today I had a followup appointment with a young adult male with severe intellectual disabilities. He is barely verbal. Several weeks ago his caregiver told me that this young man often pointed to his chest and would say “hurt” or “heart,” they weren’t sure which. He also seemed to have gotten pickier about his food, and would literally pick at the food on his plate as if examining it. His appetite was definitely down, but he hadn’t lost any weight yet.

Jimmy is young and slender, not a smoker, and has no cardiovascular disease in his family, so I prescribed him omeprazole.

“So, how’s Jimmy doing?” I asked.

Continue reading …

Your patients are rating you online: How to respond. Manage your online reputation: A social media guide. Find out how.

[Read More …]

https://www.kevinmd.com/blog/2018/10/when-patients-cant-tell-you-their-symptoms.html

summary: The doctor inside never truly rests
title: The doctor inside never truly rests
body:
People like to think the worst about doctors: We don’t listen, we don’t care, we only want your money. But, the truth is we do care, and that is why most of us answered the calling to become doctors. That is why the burnout rate for doctors is so high.

Patients hate to wait in the waiting room for too long. But, truth is, I sometimes need to take a break to cry because I just told a patient they have cancer. Of course, I can’t show that face to patients because I need to put on my strong one to give them hope, even though it tears me up inside.

When you think we aren’t listening, it might because we are processing how to tell you something. Telling a patient they have a bad disease is never an easy thing. But, through our experience, we know that diagnosis is going to alter your life. You may have walked into my exam room smiling and thinking of your next vacation, but walk out crying and planning your visit to the oncologist. While I try to answer your questions and give you hope, I secretly hate the doctor inside who just destroyed part of your world.

Continue reading …

Your patients are rating you online: How to respond. Manage your online reputation: A social media guide. Find out how.

[Read More …]

https://www.kevinmd.com/blog/2018/10/the-doctor-inside-never-truly-rests.html

summary: Child death toll hits 7 in viral outbreak at rehab centre
title: Child death toll hits 7 in viral outbreak at rehab centre
body:
Another child has died following a severe viral outbreak at a New Jersey rehabilitation centre for “medically fragile children,” bringing the death toll to seven, the facility said Wednesday.

Read more from CTV Health News https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/child-death-toll-hits-7-in-viral-outbreak-at-rehab-centre-1.4147540

summary: Getting back into the gym after slipping 2 discs via /r/Fitness
title: Getting back into the gym after slipping 2 discs via /r/Fitness
body:
I am a 20 y/o guy with 3 solid years of gym experience. Following an unfortunate afternoon 4 months ago, I went to the hospital and got diagnosed with L4 and L5 slipped discs. I was told to take a break from working out for at least a month. Fast forward 4 months later and I’m feeling just as shitty as when I got my diagnosis. A different doctor however told me that exercises that strengthen my core and don’t put stress on my spine would be greatly beneficial. I’ve gained weight and feel like trash without working out. I also feel my strength waning. What would you recommend I do?



Submitted October 24, 2018 at 06:34AM by ZeInfamousHobo
via reddit https://ift.tt/2SeJVqD

title: Neutral grip pull ups via /r/Fitness
body:
So I bought a door way pull up bar. And due to my door way being way too thick, I can not access the pull up/chin up grip. So I’m left with the side grip (neutral grip). Is there a big disadvantage of just doing these? Will they help with pull up strength? Also any solutions to this?



Submitted October 24, 2018 at 03:49AM by lonelinesss
via reddit https://ift.tt/2POyUdX

summary: The concentration of a chemical in the air that is released by people when stressed is an objective indicator for setting the...
caption: The concentration of a chemical in the air that is released by people when stressed is an objective indicator for setting the age rating of films, finds a new study. The more nervous moviegoers are, the more isoprene they emit - a measurable indication of how stressful a film is.

reblog.comment: The concentration of a chemical in the air that is released by people when stressed is an objective indicator for setting the age rating of films, finds a new study. The more nervous moviegoers are, the more isoprene they emit - a measurable indication of how stressful a film is.
